metadata.title: The lure of aggregates and the pitfalls of the patriarchal perspective: a critique of the high wage economy interpretation of the British industrial revolution

relevance.topic: Critique of the high wage economy interpretation of the British industrial revolution
relevance.relevance: The study critiques the high wage economy interpretation of the British industrial revolution, emphasizing the role of cheap female and child labor in technological adoption and industrialization.
technologies: Smelting of iron ore using coal

design.sample_characteristics: Focus on working-class families in Britain during the industrial revolution, particularly those with large family sizes and reliance on male breadwinners.

independent_variables: Availability of cheap female and child labor

key_themes: Role of female and child labor
text_fragments: The account of the high wage economy is misleading because it focuses on men and male wages, underestimates the relative caloric needs of women and children.
Mechanization promised savings by not only replacing expensive male labour with capital but also by replacing it with cheap female and child labour.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides a critique of the high wage economy interpretation of the British industrial revolution, arguing that it overlooks the role of cheap female and child labor in driving technological adoption and industrialization.

technological_changes: Smelting of iron ore using coal
historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of industrialization in Britain, characterized by technological advancements and changes in labor dynamics.
historical_context.institutional_context: Focus on the patriarchal perspective and the neglect of female and child labor in historical accounts of the industrial revolution.

outcomes.main_findings: The high wage economy interpretation is misleading as it overlooks the role of cheap female and child labor in the industrial revolution.
outcomes.conclusions: The industrial revolution was driven not only by high male wages but also by the availability of cheap female and child labor, which facilitated technological adoption.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The study critiques the high wage economy perspective for its focus on male wages and neglect of female and child labor.
quality_assessment.coherence: The study provides a coherent critique of the high wage economy interpretation, supported by historical accounts and data.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The study uses historical narratives and data to support its critique, though it lacks quantitative analysis.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is relevant to understanding the broader dynamics of labor displacement and technological change during the industrial revolution.
